utterances: Lisse is very impressed, though, by the pictures taken the Impactor before it was vaporized by the comet.
Nobody's ever seen a comet this close up before.
There are craters, and there are bright patches.
And they're nothing like a snowball or, you know, a loose, lumpy pile of ice.
They're fantastic, nothing like we expected.
Another team member, Tony Farnham, watched from an observatory on Kitt Peak in Arizona.
Farnham says he was among the last on the team to see how things went because the Web site carrying the pictures was swamped.
Fortunately, he had a telescope of his own.
What I saw through the telescope--I was taking a series of three images.
We did not see an impact flash at the time of impact.
But after that, it brightened gradually.
Images taken from the Hubble telescope show the debris spread over a thousand miles out into space.
Carey Lisse, on Hawaii, says it's time to break out the champagne, but he's at 14,000 feet, and alcohol isn't allowed.
The air is thin, and it's intoxicating enough just being there.
David Kestenbaum, NPR News.
Here's an interesting bit of data for you - African-American women are much more likely to vote this November than any other voting group.
And they vote in greater numbers than African-American men.
In 2012, the last general presidential election, more than 70 percent of black women turned out to vote compared to about 61 percent of black men.
That according to the census.
In Philadelphia, there's a project trying to get more black men to the polls by recruiting barbers.
Katie Colaneri reports from member station WHYY.
Hey, my man.
Leroy Robinson Jr. owns a barbershop in West Philadelphia, and he's been doing this work for 40 years.
My father's a barber, my brother is a barber and here I am.
He says the best part of his job is talking to his customers about everything.
Right now, the political thing is on the horizon, but the biggest thing right now is Villanova.
Robinson is part of a project trying to get barbers like him to focus less on local NCAA champions and more on the political thing this election year.
The project is called Sharp Insight, and it's the brain-child of a guy named Duerwood Beale.
A former rapper turned local nonprofit director, Beale has been doing outreach work in barbershops for about 20 years because they're the ideal place to reach men of color of all ages.
When she turns, Coraline sees her eyes.
(Soundbite of movie ""Coraline"")
Professor ADOLPHUS BELK JR. (Winthrop University): For the first time in a very, very long time, we see people talking about - from coast to coast - the concerns of black women.

And hopefully this will be more than the typical election year lip service, when people began to look more carefully at what these women are thinking about and what they're trying to deal with - issues of economic security, fear about job loss, wages, children's education, so on and so forth.
Sandra Gordon(ph) teaches at a school inside Rock Hill's Freedom Center.
She hasn't picked a candidate yet, but when she does, Gordon says race and gender will not be a factor.
Others said the same thing.
To Gordon, if women make their choice based on anything but the issues, they're making a mistake.
Don't look at what they look like in color.
Don't look like what they look like in gender.
Go by what they are really stressing in their campaigns and base your decision on it.
Political observers are fascinated that so many members of such a key demographic are still undecided.
Some experts think that some women will likely walk into the voting booth tomorrow not knowing if they'll vote for Clinton or Obama.
Bernice Oats, the 56-year-old Freedom Center administrator, says she's been voting in presidential primaries for 30 years and has never had this much difficulty picking a candidate.
If they said I had to vote right this minute, I couldn't - I really - I'll probably just close my eyes.
That's how close it is.
I would just close my eyes do the mix-up thing and punch, you know...
As she speaks, Oats reaches out one of her hands as if to make a random selection of either Clinton or Obama.
The candidates would likely prefer a more decisive endorsement tomorrow.
But with a key Southern primary at stake, they'll be happy to get votes any way they can.
For NPR News, I'm Scott Graf.
We turn now to Farai Chideya.
She's the host of NPR's NEWS & NOTES, which usually airs from our studios here at NPR West.
But this week Farai is broadcasting from Columbia, South Carolina.
Hi, Farai.
Hey, how you doing, Madeleine?
Now, you have talked to all three top Democrats there.
And what was it like talking to them one on one?
It was really amazing to parse out some of the differences in approach, and also to try to get a sense of where they were emotionally.

Senator Obama was actually quite frustrated with one of the questions we asked about the now largely debunked conversation about whether or not he was a Muslim and whether he went to a madrasah or an Islamic school.
As he pointed out, it's not just about truth squatting this conversation; it's about whether or not the conversation is designed to really smear Muslims.

To talk to Senator Edwards, he really brought up how he feels responsible, as someone who's a first generation person of wealth, to give back to poor communities, which has largely been a part of his platform.
And Senator Clinton really spoke quite emotionally about why she has championed the rights of children, how her mother probably would have been in foster care if her mother were living today.
She had a very rough life, her mother did.
And that's had a profound influence on Senator Clinton.
So it was nice to see the texture of how they spoke and to get some personal stories.
Mm-hmm.
And you've also been out and about talking to voters and regular people.
And you know, as we heard in a piece just prior to this conversation, a lot of African-American women are having a tough time making a decision - making up their minds as to who they should choose.
What are they telling you?
Well, down here what we have largely heard is that African-American women are saying, you know, is the candidate pushing my issue?
And the top three issues here are education, jobs and health care.
So when it comes to those issues that you mentioned, which candidate comes out on top for the voters?
We've had people from all walks of life, and we interviewed a lot of students on purpose who support Edwards, who support Obama, and who support Clinton.
So I don't think that, you know, any of them is out of the bounds of what people here want to hear.

Because, you know, I read something - actually an editorial in the Amsterdam News, which is an African-American newspaper in New York - saying, look, if African-Americans voted on issues, Senator Edwards should be their leading candidate.
Well, we certainly talked to a young man here who supports Edwards, and we also spoke to actor Danny Glover.
And Senator Edwards has campaigned really on this issue of ending poverty.
And that's something obviously that African-American voters care about.
And as I mentioned, Senator Edwards appears to be moving up actually a little bit on Senator Clinton.
But both of those candidates are behind Senator Obama.
You're broadcasting from Columbia, South Carolina, the capital.
But did you visit other parts of the state?
We went specifically to Dillon, South Carolina, which is part of what's called the corridor of shame; it runs along I-95.
There are a whole bunch of rural schools that have been really impoverished, the kind of schools that never meet No Child Left Behind standards.
And more than that, the principal of the school, Dillon's middle school, told us that some of the kids cannot read their full alphabet.
These are seventh and eighth graders.
And she is outraged.
Basically, a lot of the parents have lost their jobs.
Sixty percent of the parents in Dillon don't even have a high school education.
Also, when we were there, Senator Obama was there for a rally.
All three of the top Democratic contenders had come down, and it's a very visible way for them to say education is a priority.
Farai Chideya, host of NPR's NEWS & NOTES, reporting and broadcasting from Columbia, South Carolina this week.
Thanks, Farai.
Thanks, Madeleine.
Today more than 1,200 people from Yemen find out if they must return home.
The U.N.
called their country the world's worst humanitarian disaster.
Economic collapse and disease followed a civil war and the intervention of outside powers, including Saudi Arabia supported by the U.S.
Now, with the help of a $250,000 grant from the Night Foundation, Beale is trying to get barbers themselves to give out information with the goal of getting more black men to the polls.
That arm won't do you any good.
And so our thinking about that is, is it almost certainly has to do with wound healing.
Salamanders heal their wounds very differently than a mammal does.
They do it very rapidly, there's very little bleeding.
If you cut off the arm in a mammal, you know, the animal would bleed to death within minutes.
So it's something like that.
And then if it raises issues about how we respond to infection.
And so I think you can make the case for why it would be very hard for a mammal in the wild during the course of evolution to evolve the ability to regenerate.
And in fact, what they do is we have to close our wounds in a way that prevents us from dying from infection and bleeding to death.
But in doing that it probably doesn't allow us to regenerate.
David Gardiner is a research biologist at the University of California Irvine.
Thanks very much.
Well, it was a pleasure.
Thank you very much.
If your dad is one of those types who pulls out the seersucker suit for Father's Day brunch, you may have wondered from time to time why is it called seersucker anyway.
It turns out the word comes from India where the fabric was invented.
Shir-o-shakar is Hindi, and it means milk and sugar representing the two textures in the fabric.
The milk being smooth and the sugar being crinkly.
That's William Ivey Long, a Tony Award-winning costume designer and inveterate wearer of seersucker himself.
In blue and white, it's a classic for summer men's wear.
Cool on a hot day, machine washable - what could be better?
